columns.text: In this problem, we will use straight-line depreciation to solve for the value of the asset at the time it was sold and the aftertax cashflow of the equipment being sold.

In this problem, we will use straight-line depreciation which is a fixed amount being subtracted to the value of the asset annually until the end of its lifespan. In order to solve for the depreciation rate, we will simply divide $100\%$ by the lifespan which is $8$ in this case.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Rate}&=\dfrac{100\%}{8}\\[15 pt]
&=12.5\%
\end{aligned}$$

This means that every year, $12.5\%$ of the initial value is subtracted to the value of the asset.
To solve the value of the asset at the end of $5$ years, we can simply take $12.5\%$ of the initial value and multiply it by $5$. The result will then be subtracted from the initial value.

Solving for the annual straight-line depreciation:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$680,000 \times 0.125\\[15 pt]
&=\$85,000
\end{aligned}$$

Every year, $\$85,000$ is subtracted from the original value.

Multiply the depreciation value and subtract it from the initial value to get the book value at the end of Year 5

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Book value}&=\$680,000 - (\$85,000 \times 5)\\[15 pt]
&=\$255,000
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the value of the asset at the end of Year 5 is $\$255,000$

We will now get the difference between the book value and the amount it was sold.

$$\begin{aligned}
\$255,000-\$143,000&=\$112,000
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the asset was sold $\$112,000$ below the book value.

Now that we have this value, we will solve for the tax break. A tax break is the amount of cash saved by the project based on the value of the depreciation of the asset being reviewed. To get this, we will simply multiply the value we obtained in Step 6 by the tax rate.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Tax break}&=\$112,000 \times 0.21\\[15 pt]
&=\$23,520
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the company saved $\$23,520$ in taxes.

To solve for the aftertax cashflow after selling this asset, we need data on the net income. Since it is not provided in the problem, we can simply solve for the effect of the sale on the cashflow. To do this, we can simply add the sell price and the tax break.

$$\begin{aligned}
\$143,000 +\$23,520&=\$166,520
\end{aligned}$$

This means that after taxes, there is an increase of $\$166,520$ in the cashflow of the project after selling the asset.
